utterances: Yesterday, officials with the National Institutes of Health finally issued their new decision-making framework.

Some public health experts who've been following this debate say it's good to have this new system but they still have concerns.
I worry that the framework might allow experiments with those strains that are scientifically interesting but unlikely to change the way we confront the next flu pandemic.
Marc Lipsitch is an epidemiologist with the Harvard School of Public Health, who says the work does have risks.
I have yet to hear a compelling rationale for why any of the proposed experiments is likely to be the best way to get a vaccine or a realistic way to improve surveillance.
The director of the office of science policy at the National Institutes of Health is Amy Patterson.
She says that a lot of this will just come down to a judgment call.
I don't think that there's any way around that.
They're not going to be necessarily black and white decisions that can be made.
She says if this review process had existed before the two controversial experiments were done, both would have been approved.
